Solving combinatorial optimization problems using QAOA

In this tutorial, we introduce combinatorial optimization problems, explain approximate optimization algorithms, explain how the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) works and present the implementation of an example that can be run on a simulator or on a 5 qubit quantum chip

  2. Examples

1. Introduction

Combinatorial optimization 1 means searching for an optimal solution in a finite or countably infinite set of potential solutions. Optimality is defined with respect to some criterion function, which is to be minimized or maximized, which is typically called the cost function.

There are various types of optimization problems. These include Minimization: cost, distance, length of a traversal, weight, processing time, material, energy consumption, number of objects. Maximization: profit, value, output, return, yield, utility, efficiency, capacity, number of objects. Any maximization problem can be cast in terms of a minimization problem and vice versa. Hence the general form a combinatorial optimization problem is given by

maximize C(x)maximize C(x)
subject to x∈Ssubject to x∈S

where x∈Sx∈S, is a discreet variable and C:D→RC:D→R is the cost function. That maps from some domain SS in to the real numbers RR. The variable xx can be subject to a set of constraints and lies within the set S⊂DS⊂D of feasible points.

In binary combinatorial optimization problems, the cost function can typically be expressed as a sum of terms that only involve a subsets Q⊂[n]Q⊂[n] of the nn bits in the string x∈{0,1}nx∈{0,1}n . The cost function CC typically written in the canonical form

C(x)=∑(Q,Q¯¯¯¯)⊂[n]w(Q,Q¯¯¯¯)∏i∈Qxi∏j∈Q¯¯¯¯(1−xj),C(x)=∑(Q,Q¯)⊂[n]w(Q,Q¯)∏i∈Qxi∏j∈Q¯(1−xj),

where xi∈{0,1}xi∈{0,1} and w(Q,Q¯¯¯¯)∈Rw(Q,Q¯)∈R. We want to find the n-bit string xx for which C(x)C(x) is the maximal.

1.1 Diagonal Hamiltonians

This cost function can be mapped to a Hamiltonian that is diagonal in the computational basis. Given the cost-fucntion CC this Hamiltonian is then written as

H=∑x∈{0,1}nC(x)|x⟩⟨x|H=∑x∈{0,1}nC(x)|x⟩⟨x|

where x∈{0,1}nx∈{0,1}n labels the computational basis states |x⟩∈C2n|x⟩∈C2n. If the cost function only has has at most weight kk terms, i.e. when only QQ conribute that involve at most Q≤kQ≤k bits, then this diagonal Hamiltonian is also only a sum of weight kk Pauli ZZ operators.

The expansion of HH in to Pauli ZZ operators can be obtained from the cannonical expansion expantion of the cost-function CC by substituting for every binary variable xi∈{0,1}xi∈{0,1} the matrix xi→2−1(1−Zi)xi→2−1(1−Zi). Here ZiZi is read as the Pauli ZZ operator that acts on qubit ii and trivial on all others, i.e.

Zi=(100−1).Zi=(100−1).

This means that the spin - Hamiltonian encoding the classical cost funtion is written as a |Q||Q| - local quantum spin Hamiltonain only involving Pauli ZZ- operators.

H=∑(Q,Q¯¯¯¯)⊂[n]w(Q,Q¯¯¯¯)12|Q|+|Q¯¯¯¯|∏i∈Q(1−Zi)∏j∈Q¯¯¯¯(1+Zj).H=∑(Q,Q¯)⊂[n]w(Q,Q¯)12|Q|+|Q¯|∏i∈Q(1−Zi)∏j∈Q¯(1+Zj).

Now, we will assume that only a few (polynomially many in nn) w(Q,Q¯¯¯¯)w(Q,Q¯) will be non-zero. Morover we will assume that the set |(Q,Q¯¯¯¯)||(Q,Q¯)| is bounded and not too large. This means we can write the cost function as well as the Hamiltonain HH as sum of mm local terms C^kC^k,

H=∑k=1nC^k,H=∑k=1nC^k,

where both mm and the support of C^kC^k is reasonably bounded.

2 Examples:

We consider 2 examples to illustrate combinatorial optimization problems. We will only implement the first example as in Qiskit, but provide a sequnce of excersises that give the instructions to implement the second example as well.

2.1 (weighted) MAXCUTMAXCUT

Consider an nn-node non-directed graph G = (V, E) where |V| = n with edge weights wij>0wij>0, wij=wjiwij=wji, for (j,k)∈E(j,k)∈E. A cut is defined as a partition of the original set V into two subsets. The cost function to be optimized is in this case the sum of weights of edges connecting points in the two different subsets, crossing the cut. By assigning xi=0xi=0 or xi=1xi=1 to each node ii, one tries to maximize the global profit function (here and in the following summations run over indices 0,1,...n-1)

C(x)=∑i,j=1nwijxi(1−xj).C(x)=∑i,j=1nwijxi(1−xj).

To simplify notation, we assume unifrom weights wij=1wij=1 for (i,j)∈E(i,j)∈E. In order to find a solution to this problem on a quantum computer, one needs first to map it to a diagonal Hamiltonian as discussed above. We write the sum as a sum over edges in the set (i,j)=E(i,j)=E

C(x)=∑i,j=1nwijxi(1−xj)=∑(i,j)∈E(xi(1−xj)+xj(1−xi))C(x)=∑i,j=1nwijxi(1−xj)=∑(i,j)∈E(xi(1−xj)+xj(1−xi))

To map is to a spin Hamiltonain we make the assignment xi→(1−Zi)/2xi→(1−Zi)/2, where ZiZi is the Pauli Z operator that has eigenvalues ±1±1 and obtain X→HX→H

H=∑(j,k)∈E12(1−ZjZk).H=∑(j,k)∈E12(1−ZjZk).

This means that the Hamiltonian can be written as a sum of m=|E|m=|E| local terms C^e=12(1−Ze1Ze2)C^e=12(1−Ze1Ze2) with e=(e1,e2)∈Ee=(e1,e2)∈E.

2.2 Constraint satisfaction problems and MAX3−SATMAX3−SAT.

Another set of examples of a combinatorial optimizatino problem is 3−SAT3−SAT. Here the cost function C(x)=∑mk=1ck(x)C(x)=∑k=1mck(x) is a sum of clasuses ck(x)ck(x) that constrain the values of 33 bits of some x∈{0,1}nx∈{0,1}n that participate in the clause. Consider for instance this example of a 3−SAT3−SAT clause

c1(x)=(1−x1)(1−x3)x132c1(x)=(1−x1)(1−x3)x132

for a bit string x∈{0,1}133x∈{0,1}133. The clause can only be satisfied by setting the bits x1=0x1=0,x3=0x3=0 and x132=1x132=1. The 3−SAT3−SAT problem now asks whether there is a bit -string that satisfies all of the mm clauses or whether no such string exists. This decision problem is the prime example of a problem that is NPNP- complete.

The closely related optimization problem MAX3−SATMAX3−SAT asks to find the bit string xx that satisfies the maximal number of of clauses in C(x)C(x). This can of course be turned again in to a decision problem if we ask where there exists a bit string that satisfies more than m~m~ of the mm clauses, which is again NPNP-complete.

3. Approximate optimization algorithms

Both the previsously considederd problems MAXCUTMAXCUT and MAX3−SATMAX3−SAT are actually known to be a NP-hard problems 1. In fact it turns out that many combinatorial optimization problems are computationally hard to solve in general. In light of this fact, we can't expect to find a provably efficient algorithm, i.e. an algorithm with polynomial runtime in the problem size, that solves these problems. This also applies to quantum algorithms. One possible approach to such problems is to develop heuristic algortihm that don't have a polynomial runtime gurantee but appear to perform well on some instances of such problems. Another alternative are approximate algorithms.

Approximate optimization algorithms find approximate solutions to NPNP-hard optimization problems. These algorithms are efficient and provide a provable guarantee on how close the approximate solution is to the actual optimum of the problem.

The guarantee typicall comes in form of an approximation ratio, α≤0α≤0. A probabilistic approximate optimization algorithm guarantees that it produces a bit-string x∗∈{0,1}nx∗∈{0,1}n so that with high probability we have that with a postive Cmax=maxxC(x)Cmax=maxxC(x)

Cmax≥C(x∗)≥αCmax.Cmax≥C(x∗)≥αCmax.

For the MAXCUTMAXCUT problem there is a famous approximate algorithm due to Goemans and Williamson 2 . This algorithm is based on an SDP relaxation of the original problem combined with a probabilistic rounding techinque that yields an with high probabilty approxiamte solution x∗x∗ that has an approximation ratio of α≈0.868α≈0.868. This approximation ratio is actually believed to optimal so that we do not expect to see an improvement by using a quantum algorithm.

4. The QAOA algorithm

The Quantum approximate optimization algorithm (QAOA) by Farhi, Goldsone and Gutmann 3takes the approach of classical aproximate algorithms and looks for a quantum analogue that will likewise produce a classical bit -string x∗x∗ that with high probabilty is expected to have a good approximation ratio αα. Before discussing the details, let us first present the general idea of this approach.

4.1 Overview:

We want to find a quantum state |ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩, that depends on some real paramters γ⃗ ,β⃗ ∈Rpγ→,β→∈Rp, which has the property that it maximizes the expectation vaue with repect to the problem Hamiltonian HH. Given this trial state we search for for parameters γ⃗ ∗,β⃗ ∗γ→∗,β→∗ that maximize Fp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )=⟨ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )|H|ψp(α⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩Fp(γ→,β→)=⟨ψp(γ→,β→)|H|ψp(α→,β→)⟩.

Once we have such a state and the corresponding parameters we prepare the state |ψp(γ⃗ ∗,β⃗ ∗)⟩|ψp(γ→∗,β→∗)⟩ on a quantum computer and measure the state in the ZZ basis |x⟩=|x1,…xn⟩|x⟩=|x1,…xn⟩ to obtain a random outcome x∗x∗.

We will see that this random x∗x∗ is going to be a bit-string that is with high probability close to the expected value Mp=Fp(γ⃗ ∗,β⃗ ∗)Mp=Fp(γ→∗,β→∗). Hence, if MpMp is close to CmaxCmax so is C(x∗)C(x∗).

4.2 The components of the QAOA algorithm.

4.2.1 The QAOA trial state

Central to QAOA is the trial state |ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩ that will be prepared on the quantum computer. Ideally we want this state to give rise to a large expectation value Fp(α⃗ ,β⃗ )=⟨γ⃗ ,β⃗ )|H|ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩Fp(α→,β→)=⟨γ→,β→)|H|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩ with respect to the problem Hamiltonian HH. In CITE Farhi, the trial states |ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩ are constructed from the problem Hamiltonian HH together with single qubit Pauli XX rotations. That means, given a problems Hamiltonian

H=∑k=1mC^kH=∑k=1mC^k
diagonal in the computational basis and a transverse field Hamiltonian
B=∑i=1nXiB=∑i=1nXi
the trial state is prepared by applying pp alternating unitaries

|ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩=e−iβpBe−iγpH…e−iβ1Be−iγ1H|+⟩n|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩=e−iβpBe−iγpH…e−iβ1Be−iγ1H|+⟩n

to the product state |+⟩n|+⟩n with X|+⟩=|+⟩X|+⟩=|+⟩.

This particular ansatz has the advantage that there exists an explicit choice for the vectors γ⃗ ∗,β⃗ ∗γ→∗,β→∗ such that for Mp=Fp(α⃗ ∗,β⃗ ∗)Mp=Fp(α→∗,β→∗) when we take the limit limp→∞Mp=Cmaxlimp→∞Mp=Cmax. This follows by viewing the trial state |ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩ as the state that follows from troterizing the adiabatic evolution with respect to HH and the transverse field Hamiltonian BB, c.f. Ref 3.

Converesely the disatvantage of this trial state is one would typically want a state that has been generated from a quantum cicruit that is not too deep. Here depth is measured with respect to the gates that can be applied directly on the quantum chip. Hence there are other proposal that suggest using Ansatz trial state that are more tailerod to the Hardware of the quantum chip Ref. 4, Ref. 5.

4.2.2 Computing the expectation value

An important component of this approach is that we will have to compute or estimate the expectation value

Fp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )=⟨ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )|H|ψp(α⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩Fp(γ→,β→)=⟨ψp(γ→,β→)|H|ψp(α→,β→)⟩
so we can optimize the parameters γ⃗ ,β⃗ γ→,β→. We will be considering two scenarios here.

Classical evaluation

Note that when the circuit to prepare |ψp(α⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩|ψp(α→,β→)⟩ is not too deep it may be possible to evaluate the expectation value FpFp classically.

This happpens for instance when one considers MAXCUTMAXCUT for graphs with bounded degree and one considers a circuit with p=1p=1. We will see an example of this in the Qiskit implementation below (section 5.2) and provide an exercise to compute the expectation value.

To illustrate the idea, recall that the Hamiltonian can be written as a sum of individual terms H=∑mk=1C^kH=∑k=1mC^k. Due to the linearlity of the expectation value, it is sufficient to consider the expectation values of the individual summands. For p=1p=1 one has that

⟨ψ1(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )|C^k|ψ1(α⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩=⟨+n|eiγ1Heiβ1B|C^k|e−iβ1Be−iγ1H|+n⟩.⟨ψ1(γ→,β→)|C^k|ψ1(α→,β→)⟩=⟨+n|eiγ1Heiβ1B|C^k|e−iβ1Be−iγ1H|+n⟩.

Observe that with B=∑ni=1XiB=∑i=1nXi the unitary e−iβ1Be−iβ1B is actually a product of single qubit rotations about XX with an angle ββ for which we will write X(β)k=exp(iβXk)X(β)k=exp⁡(iβXk).

All the individual rotations that don't act on the qubits where C^kC^k is supported commute with C^kC^k and therefore cancel. This does not increase the support of the operator C^kC^k. This means that the second set of unitary gates e−iγ1H=∏ml=1Ul(γ)e−iγ1H=∏l=1mUl(γ) have a large set of gates Ul(γ)=)e−iγ1C^lUl(γ)=)e−iγ1C^l that commute with the operator eiβ1BC^ke−iβ1Beiβ1BC^ke−iβ1B. The only gates Ul(γ)=e−iγ1C^lUl(γ)=e−iγ1C^l that contribute to the expectation value are those which involve qubits in the support of the original C^kC^k.

Hence, for bounded degree interaction the support of eiγ1Heiβ1BC^ke−iβ1Be−iγ1Heiγ1Heiβ1BC^ke−iβ1Be−iγ1H only expands by an amount given by the degree of the interaction in HH and is therefore independent of the sytem size. This means that for these smaller sub problems the expectation values are independedt of nn and can be evaluate classcially. The case of a general degree 33 is considered in 3.

This is a general observation, which means that if we have a problem where the circuit used for the trial state prepartion only increases the support of each term in the Hamiltonian by a constant amount the cost function an be directly evaluated.

When this is the case, and only a few parameters β,γβ,γ are needed in the pereparation of the trial state, these can be found easily by a simple grid search. Furthermore, an exact optimal value of MpMp can be used to bound the approximation ratio

MpCmax≥αMpCmax≥α

to obtain an estimate of αα. For this case the QAOA algorithm has the same characteristcs as a conventional approximate optimization algorithm that comes with a garanteed approximation ratio that can be obtained with polynomail efficiency in the problem size.

Evaluation on a quantum computer

When the quantum circuit becomes to deep to be evalauted classically, or when the connectivity of the Problem Hamiltonian is too high we can resort to other means of estimating the expectation value. This involves directly estimating Fp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )Fp(γ→,β→) on the quantum computer. The approach here follows the path of the conventional expectation value estimateion as used in -CITE - VQE, where a trial state |ψ(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )|ψ(γ→,β→) is prepared directly on the quantum computer and the expectation value is obtained from sampling.

Since QAOA has a diagonal Hamiltonain HH it is actually straight forward to estimate the expectation value. We only need to obtain samples from the trial state in the computational basis. Recall that H=∑x∈{0,1}nC(x)|x⟩⟨x|H=∑x∈{0,1}nC(x)|x⟩⟨x| so that we can obtain the sampling estimate of

⟨ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )|H|ψp(α⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩=∑x∈{0,1}nC(x)|⟨x|ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩|2⟨ψp(γ→,β→)|H|ψp(α→,β→)⟩=∑x∈{0,1}nC(x)|⟨x|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩|2

by repreated single qubit measurements of the state |ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩ in the ZZ - basis. For every bit - string xx obtained from the distribution |⟨x|ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩|2|⟨x|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩|2 we evaluate the cost function C(x)C(x) and avarage it over the the total number of samples. The resulting empirical avarage approximates the expectation value up to an additive sampling error that lies within the varaince of the state. The variance will be discussed below.

With access to the expectaion value, we can now run a classical optimization algorithm, such as 6, to optimize the FpFp.

While this approach does not lead to an a-priori approximation guaratee for x∗x∗, the optimzed function value can be used later to provide an estimate for the approximation ratio αα.

4.3.3 Obtaining a good approximate solution with high probability

The algorithm is naturally probabilistic in nature and produces random bit strings from the ditribution |⟨x|ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩|2|⟨x|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩|2. So how can we be sure that we will sample an approximation x∗x∗ that is close to the value of the optimized expectation value MpMp? Note that this question is also relvant to the estimation of MpMp on a quantum computer in the first place. If the samples drawn from |⟨x|ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩|2|⟨x|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩|2 have too much variance, many samples are necessary to determine the mean.

We will draw a bit string x∗x∗ that is close to the mean MpMp with high probability when the energy as variable has little variance.

Note that the number of terms in the Hamiltonian H=∑mk=1C^kH=∑k=1mC^k are bounded by mm. Say each individual summand C^kC^k has an operator norm that can be bounded by a universal constant ∥C^k∥≤C~‖C^k‖≤C~ for all k=1…mk=1…m. Then consider

⟨ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )|H2|ψp(α⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩−⟨ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )|H|ψp(α⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩2≤=≤⟨ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )|H2|ψp(α⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩∑k,l=1m⟨ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )|C^kC^l|ψp(α⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩m2C~2⟨ψp(γ→,β→)|H2|ψp(α→,β→)⟩−⟨ψp(γ→,β→)|H|ψp(α→,β→)⟩2≤⟨ψp(γ→,β→)|H2|ψp(α→,β→)⟩=∑k,l=1m⟨ψp(γ→,β→)|C^kC^l|ψp(α→,β→)⟩≤m2C~2

where we have used that ⟨ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )|C^kC^l|ψp(α⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩≤C~2⟨ψp(γ→,β→)|C^kC^l|ψp(α→,β→)⟩≤C~2.

This means that the variance of any expetation Fp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )Fp(γ→,β→) is bounded by m2C~2m2C~2. Hence this in particular applies for MpMp. Furthermore if mm only grows polynomially in the number of qubits nn, we know that taking polynomially growing number of samples s=O(C~2m2ϵ2)s=O(C~2m2ϵ2) from |⟨x|ψp(γ⃗ ,β⃗ )⟩|2|⟨x|ψp(γ→,β→)⟩|2 will be sufficient to obtain a x∗x∗ that leads to an C(x∗)C(x∗) that will be close to MpMp.

5. Qiskit Implementation

As the example implementation we consider the MAXCUTMAXCUT problem on the butterfly graph of the openly avaliable IBMQ 5-qubit chip. The graph will be defined below and corresponds to the native connectivity of the divice. This allows us to implement the original version of the QAOAQAOA algorithm, where the cost - function CC and the Hamiltonian HH that is used to generate the state coincide. Moreover, for such a simple graph the exact cost function can be calculated analytically. To implement the circuit, we follow the notation and gate defintions from the Qiskit Documentation.

As the first step will will load Qiskit and additional python packages.

%matplotlib inline
# useful additional packages 

#import math tools
import numpy as np

# We import the tools to handle general Graphs
import networkx as nx

# We import plotting tools 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
from   matplotlib import cm
from   matplotlib.ticker import LinearLocator, FormatStrFormatter

# importing Qiskit
from qiskit import Aer, IBMQ
from qiskit import QuantumRegister, ClassicalRegister, QuantumCircuit, execute

from qiskit.providers.ibmq      import least_busy
from qiskit.tools.monitor       import job_monitor
from qiskit.visualization import plot_histogram

5.1 Problem definition

We define the cost function in terms of the butterfly graph of the superconducting chip. The graph has n=5n=5 vertices V={0,1,2,3,4,5}V={0,1,2,3,4,5} and six edges E={(0,1),(0,2),(1,2),(3,2),(3,4),(4,2)}E={(0,1),(0,2),(1,2),(3,2),(3,4),(4,2)}, which will all carry the same unit weight wij=1wij=1. We load an additional network package to encode the graph and plot connectivity below.

# Generating the butterfly graph with 5 nodes 
n     = 5
V     = np.arange(0,n,1)
E     =[(0,1,1.0),(0,2,1.0),(1,2,1.0),(3,2,1.0),(3,4,1.0),(4,2,1.0)] 

G     = nx.Graph()
G.add_nodes_from(V)
G.add_weighted_edges_from(E)

# Generate plot of the Graph
colors       = ['r' for node in G.nodes()]
default_axes = plt.axes(frameon=True)
pos          = nx.spring_layout(G)

nx.draw_networkx(G, node_color=colors, node_size=600, alpha=1, ax=default_axes, pos=pos)

5.2 Optimal trial state parameters

In this example we consider the case for p=1p=1, i.e. only layer of gates. The expectation value F1(γ,β)=⟨ψ1(β,γ)|H|ψ1β,γF1(γ,β)=⟨ψ1(β,γ)|H|ψ1β,γ can be calculated analytically for this simple setting. Let us discuss the steps explicityly for the Hamiltonian H=∑(j,k)∈E12(1−ZiZk))H=∑(j,k)∈E12(1−ZiZk)). Due to the linearity of the expectation value we can compute the expectaion value for the edges individually

f(i,k)(β,α)=⟨ψ1(γ,β)|12(1−ZiZk))|ψ1(γ,β)⟩.f(i,k)(β,α)=⟨ψ1(γ,β)|12(1−ZiZk))|ψ1(γ,β)⟩.

For the butterfly graph as plotted above, we observe that there are only two kinds of edges A={(0,1),(3,4)}A={(0,1),(3,4)} and B={(0,2),(1,2),(2,3),(2,4)}B={(0,2),(1,2),(2,3),(2,4)}. The edges is AA only have two neighboring edges, while the edges in BB have four. You can convince yourself that we only need to compute the expectation of a single edge in each set since the other expectation values will be the same. This means that we can compute F1(γ,β)=2fA(γ,β)+4fB(γ,β)F1(γ,β)=2fA(γ,β)+4fB(γ,β) by evaluating only computing two expectation values. Note, that following the argument as outlined in section 4.2.2, all the gates that do not intersect with the Pauli opertor Z0Z1Z0Z1 or Z0Z2Z0Z2 commute and cancel out so that we only need to compute

fA(γ,β)=12(1−⟨+3|U21(γ)U02(γ)U01(γ)X0(β)X1(β)Z0Z1X†1(β)X†0(β)U†01(γ)U†02(γ)U†12(γ)|+3⟩)fA(γ,β)=12(1−⟨+3|U21(γ)U02(γ)U01(γ)X0(β)X1(β)Z0Z1X1†(β)X0†(β)U01†(γ)U02†(γ)U12†(γ)|+3⟩)

and

fB(γ,β)=12(1−⟨+5|U21(γ)U24(γ)U23(γ)U01(γ)U02(γ)X0(β)X2(β)Z0Z2X†0(β)X†2(β)U†02(γ)U†01(γ)U†12(γ)U†23(γ)U†24(γ)|+5⟩)fB(γ,β)=12(1−⟨+5|U21(γ)U24(γ)U23(γ)U01(γ)U02(γ)X0(β)X2(β)Z0Z2X0†(β)X2†(β)U02†(γ)U01†(γ)U12†(γ)U23†(γ)U24†(γ)|+5⟩)

How complex these expectation values become in general depend only on the degree of the graph we are considering and is independent of the size of the full graph if the degree is bounded. A direct evaluation of this expression with Uk,l(γ)=expiγ2(1−ZkZl)Uk,l(γ)=exp⁡iγ2(1−ZkZl) and
Xk(β)=exp(iβXk)Xk(β)=exp⁡(iβXk) yields

fA(γ,β)=12(sin(4γ)sin(4β)+sin2(2β)sin2(2γ))fA(γ,β)=12(sin(4γ)sin(4β)+sin2(2β)sin2(2γ))

and

fB(γ,β)=12(1−sin2(2β)sin2(2γ)cos2(4γ)−14sin(4β)sin(4γ)(1+cos2(4γ)))fB(γ,β)=12(1−sin2(2β)sin2(2γ)cos2(4γ)−14sin(4β)sin(4γ)(1+cos2(4γ)))

These results can now be combined as discribed above, and we the expectation value is therefore given by

F1(γ,β)=3−(sin2(2β)sin2(2γ)−12sin(4β)sin(4γ))(1+cos2(4γ)),F1(γ,β)=3−(sin2(2β)sin2(2γ)−12sin(4β)sin(4γ))(1+cos2(4γ)),

We plot the function F1(γ,β)F1(γ,β) and use a simple grid search to find the parameters (γ∗,β∗)(γ∗,β∗) that maximize the expectation value.

# Evaluate the function
step_size   = 0.1;

a_gamma         = np.arange(0, np.pi, step_size)
a_beta          = np.arange(0, np.pi, step_size)
a_gamma, a_beta = np.meshgrid(a_gamma,a_beta)

F1 = 3-(np.sin(2*a_beta)**2*np.sin(2*a_gamma)**2-0.5*np.sin(4*a_beta)*np.sin(4*a_gamma))*(1+np.cos(4*a_gamma)**2)

# Grid search for the minimizing variables
result = np.where(F1 == np.amax(F1))
a      = list(zip(result[0],result[1]))[0]

gamma  = a[0]*step_size;
beta   = a[1]*step_size;

# Plot the expetation value F1
fig = plt.figure()
ax  = fig.gca(projection='3d')

surf = ax.plot_surface(a_gamma, a_beta, F1, cmap=cm.coolwarm, linewidth=0, antialiased=True)

ax.set_zlim(1,4)
ax.zaxis.set_major_locator(LinearLocator(3))
ax.zaxis.set_major_formatter(FormatStrFormatter('%.02f'))

plt.show()

#The smallest paramters and the expectation can be extracted
print('\n --- OPTIMAL PARAMETERS --- \n')
print('The maximal expectation value is:  M1 = %.03f' % np.amax(F1))
print('This is attained for gamma = %.03f and beta = %.03f' % (gamma,beta))

 --- OPTIMAL PARAMETERS --- 

The maximal expectation value is:  M1 = 3.431
This is attained for gamma = 1.900 and beta = 0.200

5.3 Quantum circuit

With these paramters we can now construct the circuit that prepares the trial state for the Graph or the Graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E) described above with vertex set V={0,1,2,3,4}V={0,1,2,3,4} and the edges are E={(0,1),(0,2),(1,2),(3,2),(3,4),(4,2)}E={(0,1),(0,2),(1,2),(3,2),(3,4),(4,2)}. The circuit is going to requite n=5n=5 qubits and we prepare the state

|ψ1(γ,β)⟩=e−iβBe−iγH|+⟩n.|ψ1(γ,β)⟩=e−iβBe−iγH|+⟩n.

Recall that the terms are given by B=∑k∈VXkB=∑k∈VXk and H=∑(k,m)∈E12(1−ZkZm)H=∑(k,m)∈E12(1−ZkZm). To generate the circuit we follow these steps:

  • We first implement 5 - Hadamard HH gates to generate the unifrom superposition.

  • This is follow by 66 Ising type gates Uk,l(γ)Uk,l(γ) with angle γγ along the edges (k,l)∈E(k,l)∈E. This gate can be extressed in terms of the native Qiskit gates as

    Uk,l(γ)=Cu1(−2γ)k,lu1(γ)ku1(γ)lUk,l(γ)=Cu1(−2γ)k,lu1(γ)ku1(γ)l

  • Lastly we apply single qubit XX rotations Xk(β)Xk(β) for every vertex k∈Vk∈V with ββ as angle. This gate directly parametrized as Xk(β)=Rx(2β)kXk(β)=Rx(2β)k in Qiskit.
  • In the last srep we measure the qubits in the computational basis, i.e. we perfrom a ZZ - measurement and record the resulting bit-string x∈{0,1}5x∈{0,1}5.
# preapre the quantum and classical resisters
QAOA = QuantumCircuit(len(V), len(V))

# apply the layer of Hadamard gates to all qubits
QAOA.h(range(len(V)))
QAOA.barrier()

# apply the Ising type gates with angle gamma along the edges in E
for edge in E:
    k = edge[0]
    l = edge[1]
    QAOA.cu1(-2*gamma, k, l)
    QAOA.u1(gamma, k)
    QAOA.u1(gamma, l)
    
# then apply the single qubit X - rotations with angle beta to all qubits
QAOA.barrier()
QAOA.rx(2*beta, range(len(V)))

# Finally measure the result in the computational basis
QAOA.barrier()
QAOA.measure(range(len(V)),range(len(V)))

### draw the circuit for comparison
QAOA.draw(output='mpl')

5.4 Cost function evaluation

Finally, we need a routine to compute the cost function value from the bit string. This is necessary to decide whether we have found a "good candidate" bitstring xx but could also be used to estimate the expectation value F1(γ,β)F1(γ,β) in settings where the expectation value can not be evlautated directly.

# Compute the value of the cost function
def cost_function_C(x,G):
    
    E = G.edges()
    if( len(x) != len(G.nodes())):
        return np.nan
        
    C = 0;
    for index in E:
        e1 = index[0]
        e2 = index[1]
        
        w      = G[e1][e2]['weight']
        C = C + w*x[e1]*(1-x[e2]) + w*x[e2]*(1-x[e1])
        
    return C

5a. Running QAOA on a simulator

We first run the algorithm on a local QASM simulator.

# run on local simulator
backend      = Aer.get_backend("qasm_simulator")
shots        = 10000

simulate     = execute(QAOA, backend=backend, shots=shots)
QAOA_results = simulate.result()

plot_histogram(QAOA_results.get_counts(),figsize = (8,6),bar_labels = False)

Evaluate the date from the simulation

Let us now proceed to calculate the relevant information from the simulated data. We will use the obtained results to

  • Compute the mean energy and check whether it agrees with the theoretical prediction
  • Report the sampled bitstring x∗x∗ with the largest observed cost function C(x∗)C(x∗)
  • Plot the Historgram of the energies to see whether is indeed concentrates around the prediceted mean
# Evaluate the data from the simulator
counts = QAOA_results.get_counts()

avr_C       = 0
max_C       = [0,0]
hist        = {}

for k in range(len(G.edges())+1):
    hist[str(k)] = hist.get(str(k),0)

for sample in list(counts.keys()):

    # use sampled bit string x to compute C(x)
    x         = [int(num) for num in list(sample)]
    tmp_eng   = cost_function_C(x,G)
    
    # compute the expectation value and energy distribution
    avr_C     = avr_C    + counts[sample]*tmp_eng
    hist[str(round(tmp_eng))] = hist.get(str(round(tmp_eng)),0) + counts[sample]
    
    # save best bit string
    if( max_C[1] < tmp_eng):
        max_C[0] = sample
        max_C[1] = tmp_eng
                
M1_sampled   = avr_C/shots

print('\n --- SIMULATION RESULTS ---\n')
print('The sampled mean value is M1_sampled = %.02f while the true value is M1 = %.02f \n' % (M1_sampled,np.amax(F1)))
print('The approximate solution is x* = %s with C(x*) = %d \n' % (max_C[0],max_C[1]))
print('The cost function is distributed as: \n')
plot_histogram(hist,figsize = (8,6),bar_labels = False)

 --- SIMULATION RESULTS ---

The sampled mean value is M1_sampled = 3.32 while the true value is M1 = 3.43 

The approximate solution is x* = 10100 with C(x*) = 4

5b. Running QAOA on a real quantum device

# Use the IBMQ essex device
provider = IBMQ.load_account()
backend = provider.get_backend('ibmq_essex')
shots   = 2048

job_exp = execute(QAOA, backend=backend, shots=shots)
job_monitor(job_exp)

Job Status: job has successfully run

exp_results = job_exp.result()
plot_histogram(exp_results.get_counts(),figsize = (10,8),bar_labels = False)
